description:
Fagopyrum tataricum, commonly known as Tartary buckwheat or Siberian buckwheat, is a species of buckwheat in the family Polygonaceae. It is a herbaceous annual plant that is native to Central Asia and is cultivated in various parts of the world.

The plant typically grows to a height of 30-60 cm and has triangular-shaped leaves. The flowers are small, white or pinkish, and arranged in clusters. The fruits are three-sided, dark-colored achenes (dry, one-seeded fruits) that are enclosed in a hard, woody hull.

Tartary buckwheat is valued for its nutritional properties, as it is a good source of protein, fiber, and various vitamins and minerals, including B-complex vitamins, iron, and magnesium. It is often used in the production of flour, groats, and other food products.

The plant is adapted to grow in a wide range of environmental conditions, including cool climates and poor soil. It is known for its resistance to various pests and diseases, making it a valuable crop in sustainable agricultural systems.

Overall, Fagopyrum tataricum is an important minor grain crop that has been cultivated for centuries and continues to be an integral part of the traditional diets and agricultural practices in many parts of the world.
